title: Revoliutsiia! Demonstratsiia! Introduction
transcript:
MARK STEINBERG: If there’s one word everyone thought the revolution was about, that’s freedom.

KATE TAHK: There are artists who are committed to the realization of these political goals.

MARK STEINBERG: Workers right poems about how they’re going to grow wings.

KATE TAHK: There’s a lot of debate, even within the group, as to what the right form of the proletarian artist is.

MARK STEINBERG: The world we are given is not enough, and we don’t have to accept it.

KATE TAHK: You know, a true communist society where everyone is part of collective, everyone is equal, everyone is an actor, and no one is passive.

MATT WITKOVSKY: Welcome to the Revoliutsiia! Demonstratsiia! audio tour. I’m Matt Witkovsky, curator in the Department of Photography at the Art Institute of Chicago. On the centenary of the 1917 Russian Revolution, we bring to you an exhibition that talks about the audiences and impact of early Soviet art. Where and how was Soviet art seen? By whom? For whom? And what can we learn today from the conversations opened up by that art? We hope you’ll listen in on those conversations as you walk through the exhibition — please start in the “Battleground” section and then take any path you like. You’ll also be hearing from Mark Steinberg, professor of history at the University of Illinois, Champaign-Urbana, and Kathleen Tahk, curatorial fellow here at the Art Institute.
